Yes, but that comes after:
"""
The POST method is used to request that the =
origin server accept the entity 
enclosed in the request as a new subordina=
te of the resource   identified 
by the Request-URI in the Request-Line.
""=
"

So the actual function performed by the POST method is determined by the=
 
RESOURCE identified by they URI (not the URI itself).  Subordination only=
 
has meaning based on the content-type of that resource.

The paragraph yo=
u quote also adds the constraint that the URI returned in 
the Location hea=
der in a 201 also must be subordinate in URI space to the 
POSTed URI.  Obv=
iously the server has to figure out how best to implement 
this subordinati=
on.

-Alex-

<yloiseau@...> wrote:

> Le mer 13/08/200=
3 =E0 02:17, Alex Jacobson a =E9crit :
>> --On Tuesday, August 12, 2003 9:2=
3 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau
>> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
>> > Here, you're d=
efining a generic behaviour for a container "super-type".
>>
>> No I am say=
ing that HTTP imposes strict requirements on how you interact
>> with a con=
tainer.  See the definition of POST in rfc2616.
>
> """
> The actual functi=
on performed by the POST method is determined by the
> server and is usuall=
y dependent on the Request-URI. The posted entity
> is subordinate to that =
URI in the same way that a file is subordinate
> to a directory containing =
it, a news article is subordinate to a
> newsgroup to which it is posted, o=
r a record is subordinate to a
> database.
> """
>
> I don't see where this=
 imply MoST... your proposed is based on Mime, not
> HTTP, to imply how to =
interact with the resource...
>
>
>> > These are application level specific=
ities, while Rest is
>> > communication/interaction level.
>>
>> MoST addre=
sses the same level as ReST.
>>
>> > You can define a common way to express=

>> > rules and restrictions of your application, as you can define a gener=
ic
>> > container "super-type", with the corresponding behaviours, but I th=
ing
>> > that is out of the scope of ReST...
>>
>> HTTP completely specifie=
s the meaning of HTTP methods with respect to
>> HTTP  resources.  If you a=
re defining different meanings for these
>> methods you  are violating HTTP=
.  MoST is just the observation that HTTP
>> is good.  Neither MoST nor HTT=
P says anything about the behavior of
>> agents that  interact with those r=
esources.
>>
>> -Alex-
>>
>> ______________________________________________=
_____________________
>> S. Alexander Jacobson                   i2x Media

n 11/08/2003 =E0 20:07, Alex Jacobson a =E9crit :
>> >> --On Saturday, Augu=
st 09, 2003 11:08 AM +0200 Yannick Loiseau
>> >> <yloiseau@...> wrote:
=
>> >> >> So, if you let MoST constrain your system around its formats, you
=
>> >> >> would have achieved a 1000% productivity increase.
>> >> >
>> >> >=
 Ok, so give an example.. I have to admit that i don't really
>> >> > under=
stand. You have to define a format that is suitable for any
>> >> > kind of=
 application. This look quite ambitious. You can use RDF to
>> >> > help th=
e representation to be self descriptive, but you still have
>> >> > to defi=
ne (ou refine) and RDFS. From an other pov, your proposal
>> >> > looks lik=
e wsdl (as Bill? said).
>> >>
>> >> See my comments on taking HTTP seriousl=
y in the other thread.
>> >> Earlier, you defined an inbox index format.  I=
 am saying that is
>> >> enough to  define your entire application from the=
 client's
>> >> perspective.
>> >>
>> >> If the server returns an index in =
response to a GET without an Accept
>> >> header, the resource is an index =
and NOT a container.  That means the
>> >> semantics of POST  should be wit=
h respect to that index and not a
>> >> container.  In other words, if the =
resource IS an index, then POST
>> >> means add an entry to the index and N=
OT add a message to a container;
>> >> messages must be stored somewhere el=
se a la DJ Bernstein.
>> >>
>> >> If the server returns a container in resp=
onse to a GET without an
>> >> Accept header, the resource is a container a=
nd not an index.  That
>> >> means the semantics of POST should be with res=
pect to the container
>> >> and not an index.  In other words, if the resou=
rce is a container,
>> >> then POST means add a  message to the container a=
nd can at your
>> >> option affect an index. Messages  are stored in the co=
ntainer  a la
>> >> SMTP.  Note, nothing constrains the  server from provid=
ing an index
>> >> in response to a GET with a an "Accept:  text/x-yannick-=
index", but
>> >> that is really beside the point.
>> >
